title: BUG: Remove builtins from __all__
body:
This was introduced in 3ca0eb1136102ff01bcc171f53c106326fa4445b, due to an incorrect implementation of `__dir__` (fixed in the first commit of this patch). Looks like I never finished reviewing [this part](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/14097#discussion_r309506000) of the original PR.

It was never released, so this is not a breaking change.

In that commit, `from numpy import *` would reset all the builtins to their defaults, and set `unicode = str`, `long = int`.

title: MAINT: move buffer.h -> npy_buffer.h to avoid conflicts
body:
Backport of #14830. 

Fixes gh-13281

Openssl has its own buffer.h file, move ours to avoid conflict

title: BUG: lib: Fix histogram problem with signed integer arrays.
body:
Backport of #14381. 

An input such as

    np.histogram(np.array([-2, 0, 127], dtype=np.int8), bins="auto")

would raise the exception

    ValueError: Number of samples, -1, must be non-negative.

The problem was that the peak-to-peak value for the input array was
computed with the `ptp` method, which returned negative values for
signed integer arrays when the actual value was more than the
maximum signed value of the array's data type.

The fix is to use a peak-to-peak function that returns an
unsigned value for signed integer arrays.

Closes gh-14379.

<!-- Please be sure you are following the instructions in the dev guidelines
http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html

http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message

title: BLD: Prevent -flto from optimising long double representation check away
body:
Backport of #14827. 

This was required for Python 3.8 builds for macOS on conda-forge: https://github.com/conda-forge/numpy-feedstock/pull/175

If I understand correctly, `-flto` with clang 9 was optimisng the test `struct` in the `long_double_representation` detection away causing the binary parsing to fail. This patch was enough to prevent this.

title: BLD: Prevent -flto from optimising long double representation check away
body:
Backport of #14827. 

This was required for Python 3.8 builds for macOS on conda-forge: https://github.com/conda-forge/numpy-feedstock/pull/175

If I understand correctly, `-flto` with clang 9 was optimisng the test `struct` in the `long_double_representation` detection away causing the binary parsing to fail. This patch was enough to prevent this.

A failing log can be found [here](https://dev.azure.com/conda-forge/feedstock-builds/_build/results?buildId=87523&view=logs). I think Azure will clean it at some point so I'll copy the interesting part:

title: BUG: lib: Fix histogram problem with signed integer arrays.
body:
Backport of #14381. 

An input such as

    np.histogram(np.array([-2, 0, 127], dtype=np.int8), bins="auto")

would raise the exception

    ValueError: Number of samples, -1, must be non-negative.

The problem was that the peak-to-peak value for the input array was
computed with the `ptp` method, which returned negative values for
signed integer arrays when the actual value was more than the
maximum signed value of the array's data type.

The fix is to use a peak-to-peak function that returns an
unsigned value for signed integer arrays.

Closes gh-14379.

title: BUG: Fix _ctypes class circular reference. (#13808)
body:
Backport of #14469. 

In _ctypes class, ctypes.cast() was called twice. It causes circular reference
for _ctypes._data due to the CPython bug https://bugs.python.org/issue12836.
This bug of ctypes.cast() seems affecting all Python versions.
It can be verified with the code below.
```python
from sys import getrefcount
import ctypes

z = ctypes.c_int(1)
pc = ctypes.cast(ctypes.byref(z), ctypes.c_char_p)
print(getrefcount(pc))  # 2: from getrefcount()
pv = ctypes.cast(pc, ctypes.c_void_p)
print(getrefcount(pc))  # 3: from getrefcount(), pc._objects; circular ref: pc -> pc._objects -> pc!
_objects = pc._objects
print(_objects == pv._objects)
print(getrefcount(_objects))  # 4: from getrefcount(), _objects, pc._objects, pv._objects
pc = pv = None
print(getrefcount(_objects))  # 3: from getrefcount(), _objects; circular ref: _objects -> pc -> pc._objects!
```

http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html

title: BUG: Fix nonrandom first uint32 in MT19937 state initialization.
body: Fixes gh-14844. As noted in the comments there by @rkern, the bug was to set the first byte to a value rather than to OR it with that value.

title: numpy.random.RandomState() fails silently if /dev/urandom returns nothing
body:
For some reason, I get nothing back when I run `cat /dev/urandom | base64 | head -c 5` on my system. This turns numpy deterministic silently.

### Reproducing code example:
Running

```python
import numpy as np
print(np.random.RandomState().get_state()[1][0])
print(np.random.RandomState().get_state()[1][0])
```
should print two different numbers. I get the same number twice.

### Numpy/Python version information:

1.17.3 3.7.5 (default, Oct 17 2019, 12:09:47) 
[GCC 9.2.1 20190827 (Red Hat 9.2.1-1)]

title: BLD: Prevent -flto from optimising long double representation check away
body:
This was required for Python 3.8 builds for macOS on conda-forge: https://github.com/conda-forge/numpy-feedstock/pull/175

title: Wrong result when subtracting a column of a large array from all columns
body:
Given a list of N 3d points in a 3xN array, e.g. a trajectory of some kind, you may want to eliminate the initial offset and subtract the first point coordinates from all points, so the trajectory starts at (0, 0, 0).
This only works for small arrays, unless you explicitely copy the first point.
With longer arrays (N > 2730 seems to be the breaking point on my machine), some regions of the array will stay unchanged, probably because the operation is split into several chunks all using the first colum by reference.

### Reproducing code example:

```python
import numpy as np
A = np.ones((3, 10000))  # point data, change the length to avoid/provoke the bug
t = A[:, 0, np.newaxis]  # offset
# workaround:
# t = np.array(A[:, 0, np.newaxis], copy=True)
A -= t
print(np.any(A))
```

### Expected output:
`False`

### Actual output:
`True`

### Numpy/Python version information:
NumPy 1.16.2
Python 3.5.2 (default, Oct  8 2019, 13:06:37)
GCC 5.4.0 20160609

title: BUG: random: biased samples from integers() with 8 or 16 bit dtype.
body:
Backport of #14777. 

When an 8 or 16 bit dtype was given to the integers() method of the
Generator class, the resulting sample was biased.  The problem was
the lines of the form

    const uint8_t threshold = -rng_excl % rng_excl;

in the implementations of Lemire's method, in the C file
distributions.c.  The intent was to compute
    (UINT8_MAX+1 - rng_excl) % rng_excl
However, when the type of rng_excl has integer conversion rank lower
than a C int (which is almost certainly the case for the 8 and 16
bit types), the terms in the expression -rng_excl % rng_excl are
promoted to int, and the result of the calculation is always 0.

The fix is to make the expression explicit, and write it as

    const uint8_t threshold = (UINT8_MAX - rng) % rng_excl;

rng is used, because rng_excl is simply rng + 1; by using rng, we
we only need the constant UINT#_MAX, without the extra +1.

For consistency, I made the same change for all the data types
(8, 16, 32 and 64 bit).

Closes gh-14774.

<!-- Please be sure you are following the instructions in the dev guidelines
http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html
-->

<!-- We'd appreciate it if your commit message is properly formatted
http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message
-->

title: Bias of random.integers() with int8 dtype
body:
Output of `integers()` with `dtype=int8` appears to be less uniform that one could expect it to.

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

samples = np.random.default_rng().integers(31, size=1111111, dtype=np.int8)
values, counts = np.unique(samples, return_counts=True)
plt.vlines(values, 0, counts)
plt.show()
```
![random-int8](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1221991/67503623-3b286900-f688-11e9-991d-02b186ead341.png)

Similar periodicity shows up with various static seeds and MT19937; flipping the `use_masked` flag in `random_bounded_uint8_fill()` results in all values having approximately equal frequencies.
Same for 1.17 and 1.18.0.dev0+c10d66a 3.7.3 (default, Oct  7 2019, 12:56:13) [GCC 8.3.0].

title: BUG: fix integer size confusion in handling array's ndmin argument
body:
The ndmin local variable was changed from an "int" to an "npy_intp" but
&ndmin is passed to PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords against a "i" argument
spec, but these integers have different sizes (well on an LP64 platform
anyway). This actually works on a little endian system but fails
on a big endian one. Fix this by converting the local back to an int,
and being a little careful before assigning the result of PyLong_AsLong to
it.

Fixes #14767

title: np.array([0.0, 1.0, 2.0], ndmin=2) fails on big endian system
body:
### Reproducing code example:

```python
import numpy as np
np.array([0.0, 1.0, 2.0], ndmin=2) 
```

on a big endian system, e.g. Ubuntu on s390x (which I realise is not the most accessible of platforms)

### Error message:

ValueError: ndmin bigger than allowable number of dimensions NPY_MAXDIMS (=32)

### Numpy/Python version information:

1.17.3

What's going on? Well e256762b022acf5d0df096cf178704518b782b89 changed the ndmin local variable from an "int" to an "npy_intp". On 64-bit linux int is 32 bits and npy_intp aka intptr_t is 64 bits. &ndmin is passed to PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords against a "i" argument spec ... and you can see where this is going. Casting a long* to an int* and writing through it works OK on little endian but very much does not on big endian. There's no PyArg_ParseTupleAndKeywords code for intptr_t, so the best fix is probably to change ndmin back to an int and be a little careful in the fast path that "ndmin = PyLong_AsLong(ndmin_obj)" does not overflow.

title: BUG: clear only attribute errors in get_attr_string.h::maybe_get_attr
body:
fixes #14735.

With this, filtered warnings (and all exceptions other than `AttributeError`) should be passed through. Though now raising `NotImplementedError` will also bubble up.

There are several issues with this fix and I'm not sure how to deal with them:
* I created a new test file named after the issue. This should probably go somewhere else, but I'm not sure where.
* I didn't find something similar, so I added a helper function to clear only a certain exception. Did I miss something?
* I'm also not sure whether the commentary / documentation of `maybe_get_attr` is still accurate (I didn't really understand what it meant).

Also, my knowledge of C is limited, so there may be obvious issues, especially with the signature of the helper.

@seberg, what do you think of this? I can confirm that the original issue can be avoided by explicitly adding `__array__` and warning there, so I don't have to depend on this.

title: BUG: properly define PyArray_DescrCheck
body:
Backport of #14605. 

`PyArray_DescrCheck` was defined incorrectly. Redefine and add `PyArray_DescrCheckExact`.

This becomes a problem if we allow subclassing `PyArrayDescr_Type`, and should be backported to any version we still support to prevent issues when using a newer NumPy with code compiled with an older NumPy. Searching scipy/pandas/astropy/numba only turned up a use inside numba. Once this is merged we should submit an issue there to work around this for old versions.

title: BUG: Do not rely on undefined behaviour to cast from float to datetime
body:
A cast from float to signed integer is only valid for the range of
integer, which means that a cast of a NaN to int is undefined.  On x86
cvttd2si conveniently seems to put the mantissa into the long (I
haven't done an exhaustive check to see if that is what it does, but
seems that way), which works for conversion from NaN to NaT.  On
aarch64 however, the corresponding fcvtzs sets the value to 0 for all
undefined ranges, thus breaking the cast.

This fix splits out the float -> integer conversions, explicitly
checks for NaN and sets the target value as NaT, which should make the
behaviour well defined for NaN to NaT translations.

title: BUG: random: Use correct length when axis is given to shuffle.
body:
When an axis argument was given, shuffle was using the original length of
the array instead of the length of the given axis.  This meant that, for
example, if an array with shape (2, 10) was shuffled with axis=1, only the
first two columns were shuffled.

title: BUG: fromfile with subarray dtypes is broken
body:
This I think breaks reading sub-array dtypes:
```
# After this PR
>>> import numpy as np
>>> with open('/dev/zero', 'rb') as f:
...     a = np.fromfile(f, dtype='(8,8)u8', count=1)
... 
>>> (a == 0).all()
False
```
The reason I guess is that creating an array with sub-array dtype moves the array dimensions from the dtype to the array itself, so the number of bytes to read becomes incorrect.

_Originally posted by @pv in https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/14586/files_


----

While fixing/writing tests, similar issues seem to happen in FromString. Probably it is best to switch to the old pattern of using the given dtype even though the array turns out representing it differently. At least `FromString` has a use-after-free bug with this pattern currently.

**EDIT:** I am planning to look at this, but if someone beats me to it, great :). It should not be difficult, but reference counting issues can be confusing...

Test for anyone who wants to start (it may be worth to look at some other similar paths though):
```python
    def test_subarray_into_shape(self):
        # Test subarray dtypes which are absorbed into the shape
        x = np.arange(24, dtype="i4").reshape(2, 3, 4)
        x.tofile(self.filename)
        res = np.fromfile(self.filename, dtype="(3,4)i4")
        assert_array_equal(x, res)

        x_str = x.tobytes()
        with assert_warns(DeprecationWarning):
            # binary fromstring is deprecated
            res = np.fromstring(x_str, dtype="(3,4)i4")
            assert_array_equal(x, res)
```

title: BUG: Update financial.py : Use default_type() directly
body:
**Problem** : TypeError in numpy.rate when using Decimals
For example: 
np.rate(Decimal(12), Decimal('400'), Decimal('10000'), Decimal(0))

**Output** : (TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'float' and 'Decimal')

Proposed solution
If the type of the "rn" variable is "Decimal", then do type conversion of "np.nan" to "Decimal" (to make operands for "+" operation compatible ) otherwise return as it is.

title: BUG: dtype refcount cleanups
body:
gh-13605 did not handle refcounts of dtype instances. I discovered this by running
```
python runtests.py -t numpy/core/tests/test_deprecations.py
```
which printed the following twice at the end
```
*** Reference count error detected: 
an attempt was made to deallocate 12 (d) ***
```

The lack of those reference count errors when running all the tests (before this PR) would suggest we have places in the code that leak references by incref-ing without decref-ing.

title: BUG: importing build_src breaks setuptools monkeypatch for msvc14
body:
It turns out importing `build_src` in the `setup.py` breaks a numpy-specific monkey patch of setuptools for msvc14. Not sure why this only shows up in the wheel builds. The reason for the import was to improve the help message output for `python setup.py --help-commands`.  `build_src`, a numpy-specific addition, is not listed in the `Extra commands` section.

xref MacPython/numpy-wheels#61

At some point we could revisit this, but this PR should un-break the wheel builds.

title: BUG: Fix _ctypes class circular reference. (#13808)
body:
In _ctypes class, ctypes.cast() was called twice. It causes circular reference
for _ctypes._data due to the CPython bug https://bugs.python.org/issue12836.
This bug of ctypes.cast() seems affecting all Python versions.
It can be verified with the code below.
```python
from sys import getrefcount
import ctypes

z = ctypes.c_int(1)
pc = ctypes.cast(ctypes.byref(z), ctypes.c_char_p)
print(getrefcount(pc))  # 2: from getrefcount()
pv = ctypes.cast(pc, ctypes.c_void_p)
print(getrefcount(pc))  # 3: from getrefcount(), pc._objects; circular ref: pc -> pc._objects -> pc!
_objects = pc._objects
print(_objects == pv._objects)
print(getrefcount(_objects))  # 4: from getrefcount(), _objects, pc._objects, pv._objects
pc = pv = None
print(getrefcount(_objects))  # 3: from getrefcount(), _objects; circular ref: _objects -> pc -> pc._objects!
```

title: BUG: Update 1.17.x with 1.18.0-dev pocketfft.py.
body:
Backport of #14279, 

BUG: fix issue #14176

This replaces the fct variable in pocketfft.py by its inverse, inv_fct. The actual factor is only built immediately before executing the FFT. This defers potential divide-by-zero exceptions until after the check for zero-length transforms.

The easiest way to backport #14279 was to copy `pocketfft.py` from master.
That also brings some improved documentation and other fixes with it, which
cannot hurt.

title: BUG: Fix uint-overflow if padding with linear_ramp and negative gain.
body:
Backport of #14209. 

In case end_value was greater than the edge values of the array to pad, the resulting difference was negative and caused overflows in case the input array used unsigned types. Fixed by using 1.17 version of `linspace` instead of `_linear_ramp`.

Protect against this regression with a new test for all numeric dtypes.

Fixes #14191.

title: Regression: lexsort gives wrong results on short integer types
body:
Changing the dtype of a lexsort argument like this should not change the result, but it does with numpy 1.17.0 and 1.17.1:

```python
np.lexsort((np.array([0, 1, 2, 0]), np.array([0, 0, 0, 1], dtype='int8'))) # [0, 3, 1, 2]
np.lexsort((np.array([0, 1, 2, 0]), np.array([0, 0, 0, 1], dtype='int32'))) # [0, 1, 2, 3]
```

The problem does not affect 1.16.4 so this is a regression.

```
1.17.1
3.6.1 (v3.6.1:69c0db5, Mar 21 2017, 18:41:36) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
```

(Can also reproduce on `3.7.1 (default, Dec 14 2018, 19:28:38) \n[GCC 7.3.0]` so it's not a Windows thing)

title: BUG: lib: Fix histogram problem with signed integer arrays.
body:
An input such as

    np.histogram(np.array([-2, 0, 127], dtype=np.int8), bins="auto")

would raise the exception

    ValueError: Number of samples, -1, must be non-negative.

The problem was that the peak-to-peak value for the input array was
computed with the `ptp` method, which returned negative values for
signed integer arrays when the actual value was more than the
maximum signed value of the array's data type.
 
The fix is to use a peak-to-peak function that returns an
unsigned value for signed integer arrays.

Closes gh-14379.

title: Bug: Fix behavior of structured_to_unstructured on non-trivial dtypes
body:
Fixes #13333

This fixes up some weird behavior of `structured_to_unstructured` discovered in #13333.

Performance may not be so great for dtypes with a very large subarray of structured type, but that seems like a poor situation anyway.

title: BUG: Fix formatting error in exception message
body:
Backport of #14270. 

This fixes a simple formatting error in an exception message in `random/common.pyx`. The message is supposed to contain the expected vs. the actually received dtype, but instead contained two times the expected dtype. This would lead to confusing error messages such as `Supplied output array has the wrong type. Expected <class 'numpy.float64'>, got <class 'numpy.float64'>`.

Example code to enforce the error message:
```python
import numpy as np
arr = np.zeros((1,), dtype="float32")
gen = np.random.Generator(np.random.SFC64(0))
gen.random(size=(1,), dtype="float64", out=arr)
```
Output after the fix:
```
TypeError: Supplied output array has the wrong type. Expected <class 'numpy.float64'>, got float32
```

title: BUG: Fix leak in the f2py-generated module init and `PyMem_Del` usage
body:
Backport of #14217. 

The leak is fairly innocent as the created Fortran objects are referenced from the module globals and therefore are only GCed on module reload/interpreter shutdown.

Using `PyMem_Del` is incorrect, it should be `PyObject_Del` here, while
this worked most of the time, it would lead to crashes at least on python
2.5 (after the reference counts were fixed)

title: BUG: core: Handle large negative np.int64 args in binary_repr.
body:
To avoid the cast to floating point that can occur when the first
argument to binary_repr is a NumPy integer, the argument is converted
to a Python integer at the beginning of the function.

Closes gh-14289.

title: BUG: Fix misuse of .names and .fields in various places
body:
Easiest to review commit-by-commit.

Done with the 1.16.x branch point as its base, so it can be easily backported to either 1.16 or 1.17 if desired

title: BUG: Fix ZeroDivisionError for zero length arrays in pocketfft.
body:
BUG: fix issue #14176 

This replaces the `fct` variable in `pocketfft.py` by its inverse, `inv_fct`. The actual factor is only built immediately before executing the FFT. This defers potential divide-by-zero exceptions until after the check for zero-length transforms.

title: BUG: fix inconsistent axes ordering for axis in function `unique`
body:
`unique` has is consistent axes order (except the chosen one) when `axis` is not `None` now.
Details in https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/14244.

### Change
Using `moveaxis` instead of `swapaxes` when implementation, so that the ordering
of axes except the axis in arguments will not be broken.

title: Inconsistent shape manipulation in operator `unique`
body:
Hi! I recently write a mxnet version numpy `unique`, and find there may be something wrong.

### Reproducing code example:

```python
import numpy as np
x = np.array([[[-4, -4, -2, -1],
               [ 7,  5, -1,  5],
               [ 2,  5,  0,  5]],

              [[-3,  7,  0,  0],
               [-3,  1, -2,  4],
               [-6,  6,  0,  0]],

              [[-6,  4, -7, -2],
               [ 0, -2,  0,  1],
               [ 5,  0, -1,  2]],

              [[ 5, -2, -7,  0],
               [-7,  0, -2,  0],
               [-4, -3,  6,  0]],

              [[-6,  1, -5,  5],
               [ 0,  5,  1,  5],
               [-7, -7,  5, -1]]])
np.unique(x, axis=-1)
```
The result is:
```
       [[[-4, -4, -2, -1],
         [ 7,  5, -1,  5],
         [ 2,  5,  0,  5]],
 
        [[-3,  7,  0,  0],
         [-3,  1, -2,  4],
         [-6,  6,  0,  0]],
 
        [[-6,  4, -7, -2],
         [ 0, -2,  0,  1],
         [ 5,  0, -1,  2]],
 
        [[ 5, -2, -7,  0],
         [-7,  0, -2,  0],
         [-4, -3,  6,  0]],
 
        [[-6,  1, -5,  5],
         [ 0,  5,  1,  5],
         [-7, -7,  5, -1]]])
```
### Description
In this example, the first two 'column' does not swap.

I read the source of numpy, and find it simply swap the axis before view.
In this example, for argument axis is -1 (2), the shape goes:
(5, 3, 4)->(4, 3, 5)->(4, 15)->use view->(4, )
The sequence of '5' and '3' is reversed, I think this is wrong.

If argument axis is 1, it goes:
(5, 3, 4)->(3, 5, 4)->(3, )
It's OK. So, It is obvious that when axis is -1, it should always get a wrong result.

In my implementation, the shape goes:
(5, 3, 4)->(15, 4, 1)->(4, 15, 1)->(4, 15)->use view->(4, )

I hand-write this procedure, get the shape manipulation result:
```
numpy version:
array([[-4, -3, -6,  5, -6,  7, -3,  0, -7,  0,  2, -6,  5, -4, -7],
       [-4,  7,  4, -2,  1,  5,  1, -2,  0,  5,  5,  6,  0, -3, -7],
       [-2,  0, -7, -7, -5, -1, -2,  0, -2,  1,  0,  0, -1,  6,  5],
       [-1,  0, -2,  0,  5,  5,  4,  1,  0,  5,  5,  0,  2,  0, -1]])

correct version:
array([[-4,  7,  2, -3, -3, -6, -6,  0,  5,  5, -7, -4, -6,  0, -7],
       [-4,  5,  5,  7,  1,  6,  4, -2,  0, -2,  0, -3,  1,  5, -7],
       [-2, -1,  0,  0, -2,  0, -7,  0, -1, -7, -2,  6, -5,  1,  5],
       [-1,  5,  5,  0,  4,  0, -2,  1,  2,  0,  0,  0,  5,  5, -1]])
```

### Numpy/Python version information:

numpy : 1.16
OS : MacOS
